properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Bunyip River downstream of Iona.

MINOR FLOODING IS EXPECTED TO OCCUR ON BUNYIP RIVER AT CORA LYNN FROM TOMORROW MORNING.

The Bunyip River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 17 mm since 09:00 AM Saturday 27 July 2024. The Western Port catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 13 mm for the same period. Rainfall totals of 2-5mm are forecast overnight to Monday 29th July 2024.

Water levels of the Bunyip River at various locations are rising in response to the rain.

Bunyip River downstream of Iona:

The level of the Bunyip River at Cora Lynn is currently at 2.92 metres, below the minor flood level (3.10 metres), and rising. It is expected to peak around the Minor Flood Level (3.10 metres) tomorrow morning.

Minor flooding in the Bunyip River catchment is expected to affect/affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway. The ford at Cora Lynn may be closed to traffic.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Cyclists and walkers should be wary of tracks next to rivers.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 29/07/2024 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - RIVERINE FLOOD - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Bunyip River downstream of Iona
Issue Date: Sunday 28 July 2024, 08:09 pm
Next Update: Monday 29 July 2024, 05:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/34023/moreinfo

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Bunyip River downstream of Iona.
MINOR FLOODING IS EXPECTED TO OCCUR ON BUNYIP RIVER AT CORA LYNN FROM TOMORROW MORNING.

The Bunyip River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 17 mm since 09:00 AM Saturday 27 July 2024. The Western Port catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 13 mm for the same period. Rainfall totals of 2-5mm are forecast overnight to Monday 29th July 2024.

Water levels of the Bunyip River at various locations are rising in response to the rain.

Bunyip River downstream of Iona:

The level of the Bunyip River at Cora Lynn is currently at 2.92 metres, below the minor flood level (3.10 metres), and rising. It is expected to peak around the Minor Flood Level (3.10 metres) tomorrow morning.

Minor flooding in the Bunyip River catchment is expected to affect/affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway. The ford at Cora Lynn may be closed to traffic. 

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain, Derrimut, and Cherry Lake, Altona
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain, Derrimut, and Cherry Lake, Altona.

  • Firewater has entered Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain due to the industrial fire at Swann Drive, Derrimut.
  • There may also be firewater impacts downstream at Cherry Lake.
  • The Environment Protection Authority is supporting Melbourne Water and Fire Rescue Victoria at the incident.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued on Tuesday 16 July.

You should avoid contact with the water in Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain, Derrimut, and Cherry Lake, Altona. 

Do not allow your pets to swim in or drink the water. Avoid remaining in areas where chemical odours are smelt.

What you should do:
  • Avoid contact with the water. 
  • As a precaution, do not eat fish from Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain, Derrimut, and Cherry Lake, Altona. 
  • Don’t let your pets swim in the area or drink the water.
If you come in contact with water in the warning area:
  • Remove wet clothing.
  • Wash areas of your body that have come into contact with contaminated water with warm soapy water.
  • If you are feeling unwell after coming in contact with contaminated water you can visit your doctor or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.
  • If your pets are unwell after coming in contact with contaminated water, speak to your vet. 
Impacts on the area:
  • You may see foam in the water and smell a chemical odour.
  • EPA is conducting water quality monitoring at various locations along the waterway.
  • Melbourne Water is undertaking actions including the use of booms, pumps and tankers to remove pollutants.
  • There will be multiple vehicles operating in the vicinity of the waterways.
This message was issued by Environment Protection Authority.

The next update is expected by 02/08/2024 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

ADVICE - WATER QUALITY - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain, Derrimut, and Cherry Lake, Altona
Issue Date: Friday 26 July 2024, 04:50 pm
Next Update: Friday 02 August 2024, 05:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/34019/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain, Derrimut, and Cherry Lake, Altona.

- Firewater has entered Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain due to the industrial fire at Swann Drive, Derrimut. 
- There may also be firewater impacts downstream at Cherry Lake. 
- The Environment Protection Authority is supporting Melbourne Water and Fire Rescue Victoria at the incident. 
- This Advice replaces the Advice issued on Tuesday 16 July.


You should avoid contact with the water in Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain, Derrimut, and Cherry Lake, Altona. Do not allow your pets to swim in or drink the water. Avoid remaining in areas where chemical odours are smelt.

properties.location: Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain, Derrimut, and Cherry Lake, Altona

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Terang and surrounds including Noorat and south-east of Mortlake. 
  • This Community Information replaces the Community Information issued on Friday 19 July.
  • An outbreak of high pathogenicity H7N9 Avian Influenza (HPAI) is confirmed in poultry at Terang. 
  • This warning is relevant for all bird owners including poultry producers, bird keepers and pet bird owners.
Things you should know about avian influenza:
  • Avian influenza is a highly contagious disease that infects chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, guinea fowl, quail, pheasants and ostriches. Many species of wild birds, including waterfowl and seabirds can also carry the virus.
  • To stop the spread of avian influenza, the infected properties have been quarantined.
  • Movement controls are in place
  • In Restricted and Control areas, you cannot move birds, equipment and products within and out of the area without a permit.
  • You can find more information about movement controls, quarantine and permits and access an interactive map to search for your property on the Agriculture Victoria website.
  • Cooked eggs and cooked chicken meat are safe to eat.
  • While cases among humans in direct contact with animals infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses are possible, the current risk to the public remains low.
All bird owners should regularly check their birds. If you suspect your birds are sick, contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.
What you should do:

If you own birds: 
  • Bird owners in the Terang Restricted and Control Areas should house all their poultry in cages or sheds.
  • Do not move your birds, eggs or equipment into, within or out of the Control or Restricted Areas without a permit.
  • Bird owners should regularly check their birds and immediately report any unusual signs of disease to the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226 (freecall).
  • Check the Agriculture Victoria website or phone 1800 226 226 for details on movement controls.
We may contact you:
  • We are phoning and texting residents around Terang to gather poultry and livestock details. 
  • Help us protect Victoria's poultry industry - please answer our call. 
  • Agriculture Victoria will not ask for financial information or credit card details. 
  • If you have any questions or to report sick or dead birds, contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226. 
To help prevent the spread of disease to your birds you should: 
  • Restrict contact between pet birds, poultry and wild birds. 
  • Prevent contamination of food and water by faeces or other animal waste. 
  • Keep equipment, yards and aviaries clean. 
  • Limit visitors to your birds. 
  • Bird owners should wash their hands before and after handling birds. 
Check for signs of disease: 
Signs of the disease in birds may include: 
  • Sudden death. 
  • Birds with difficulties breathing, such as coughing, sneezing, or rasping. 
  • Swelling and purple discolouration of the head, comb, wattles and neck. 
  • Rapid drop in eating, drinking and egg production. 
  • Ruffled feathers, dopiness, closed eyes. 
  • Diarrhoea. 
  • Occasionally, nervous symptoms. 
How avian influenza spreads: 
  • Avian influenza can be spread to other animals by movement of eggs, birds, people handling birds, vehicles and equipment between farms, and by clothing, footwear, aerosols, water, feed, litter, wild birds, biting insects and vermin.         
Protecting your health: 
  • You can’t contract avian influenza by eating cooked chicken meat or cooked eggs.
  • Avian influenza does not usually infect people, but in rare cases, human infection can occur.
  • Most people are not at risk, unless they have contact with infected birds or animals, or their secretions, while in affected areas of the world.
This message was issued by Agriculture Victoria.

The next update is expected by 09/08/2024 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Things you should know about avian influenza: - Avian influenza is a highly contagious disease that infects chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, guinea fowl, quail, pheasants and ostriches. Many species of wild birds, including waterfowl and seabirds can also carry the virus. - To stop the spread of avian influenza, the infected properties have been quarantined. - Movement controls are in place - In Restricted and Control areas, you cannot move birds, equipment and products within and out of the area without a permit. - You can find more information about movement controls, quarantine and permits and access an interactive map to search for your property on the Agriculture Victoria website. - Cooked eggs and cooked chicken meat are safe to eat. - While cases among humans in direct contact with animals infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses are possible, the current risk to the public remains low. All bird owners should regularly check their birds. If you suspect your birds are sick, contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Meredith and surrounds including Lethbridge, Bannockburn, Teesdale, Shelford, Inverleigh, Wingeel and Rokewood.
  • This Community Information replaces the Community Information issued on Friday 19 July.
  • An outbreak of High Pathogenicity H7N3 Avian Influenza (HPAI) is confirmed in poultry near Meredith. 
  • This warning is relevant for all bird owners including poultry producers, bird keepers and pet bird owners.
Things you should know about avian influenza:
  • Avian influenza is a highly contagious disease that infects chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, guinea fowl, quail, pheasants and ostriches. Many species of wild birds, including waterfowl and seabirds can also carry the virus.
  • To stop the spread of Avian influenza, the infected properties have been quarantined.
  • Movement controls are in place.
  • In Restricted and Control Areas, you cannot move birds, equipment and products within and out of the area without a permit.
  • You can find more information about movement controls, quarantine and permits and access an interactive map to search for your property on the Agriculture Victoria Website.
  • Cooked eggs and cooked chicken meat are safe to eat.
  • While cases among humans in direct contact with animals infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses are possible, the current risk to the public remains low.
All bird owners should regularly check their birds. If you suspect your birds are sick you should contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.
What you should do:

If you own birds:
  • Bird owners in the Meredith Restricted and Control Areas should house all their poultry in cages or sheds.
  • Do not move your birds, eggs or equipment into, within or out of the Control or Restricted areas without a permit.
  • Bird owners should regularly check their birds and immediately report any unusual signs of disease to the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226 (freecall).
  • Check the Agriculture Victoria website or phone 1800 226 226 for details on movement controls.   
We may contact you:
  • We are phoning and texting residents around Meredith to gather poultry and livestock details. 
  • Help us protect Victoria's poultry industry - please answer our call. 
  • Agriculture Victoria will not ask for financial information or credit card details. 
  • If you have any questions or to report sick or dead birds, contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226. 
To help prevent the spread of disease to your birds you should: 
  • Restrict contact between pet birds, poultry and wild birds. 
  • Prevent contamination of food and water by faeces or other animal waste. 
  • Keep equipment, yards and aviaries clean. 
  • Limit visitors to your birds. 
  • Bird owners should wash their hands before and after handling birds.
Check for signs of disease: 
Signs of the disease in birds may include:
  • Sudden death. 
  • Birds with difficulties breathing, such as coughing, sneezing, or rasping. 
  • Swelling and purple discolouration of the head, comb, wattles and neck. 
  • Rapid drop in eating, drinking and egg production. 
  • Ruffled feathers, dopiness, closed eyes. 
  • Diarrhoea.
  • Occasionally, nervous symptoms.
How avian influenza spreads: 
  • Avian influenza can be spread to other animals by movement of eggs, birds, people handling birds, vehicles and equipment between farms, and by clothing, footwear, aerosols, water, feed, litter, wild birds, biting insects and vermin.
Protecting your health: 
  • You can’t contract avian influenza by eating cooked chicken meat or cooked eggs.
  • Avian influenza does not usually infect people, but in rare cases, human infection can occur.
  • Most people are not at risk, unless they have contact with infected birds or animals, or their secretions, while in affected areas of the world.
This message was issued by Agriculture Victoria.

The next update is expected by 09/08/2024 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Laverton Creek, Altona Beach and around the Doug Grant Reserve dog off leash area.
  • Firewater has entered Laverton Creek due to an industrial fire at Swann Drive, Derrimut. 
  • There may also be firewater impacts downstream at Altona Beach and around the Doug Grant Reserve dog off leash area.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued on Tuesday 16 July.
You should avoid contact with the water in in Laverton Creek, Altona Beach and around the Doug Grant Reserve dog off leash area. 

Do not allow your pets to swim in or drink the water. Avoid remaining in areas where chemical odours are smelt.
What you should do:
  • Avoid contact with the water. 
  • As a precaution, do not eat fish from the river. 
  • Don’t let your pets swim in the area or drink the water.
If you come in contact with water in the warning area:
  • Remove wet clothing.
  • Wash areas of your body that have come into contact with contaminated water with warm soapy water.
  • If you are feeling unwell after coming in contact with contaminated water, you can visit your doctor or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.
  • If your pets are unwell after coming in contact with contaminated water, speak to your vet.
Impacts on the area:
  • You may smell chemical odours. 
  • EPA is conducting water quality monitoring at various locations along the waterway.
  • Melbourne Water is undertaking actions including the use of booms, pumps and tankers, to remove pollutants.
  • There will be multiple vehicles operating in the vicinity of the waterways.
This message was issued by Environment Protection Authority.

The next update is expected by 02/08/2024 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

ADVICE - WATER QUALITY - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Swann Dr, Derrimut
Issue Date: Friday 26 July 2024, 04:51 pm
Next Update: Friday 02 August 2024, 05:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/34020/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Laverton Creek, Altona Beach and around the Doug Grant Reserve dog off leash area.
- Firewater has entered Laverton Creek due to an industrial fire at Swann Drive, Derrimut.  
- There may also be firewater impacts downstream at Altona Beach and around the Doug Grant Reserve dog off leash area.
- This Advice replaces the Advice issued on Tuesday 16 July.


You should avoid contact with the water in in Laverton Creek, Altona Beach and around the Doug Grant Reserve dog off leash area. 

Do not allow your pets to swim in or drink the water. Avoid remaining in areas where chemical odours are smelt.
